Award.AwardTitle: Studies of Mantle Dynamics and Evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
This work will investigate the relationship between plate tectonics and the evolution of the Earth throughout its history. We will study the effects of radioactive heat sources and the viscosity of the Earth's mantle on the speed of tectonic plates and the rate of melting and heat loss at mid-ocean ridges. Our recently developed theory of mantle convection with plates on the surface has predicted different styles of plate tectonics, and we will determine how this may have influenced the thermal evolution of the Earth, the cooling of the Earth's core (which controls the magnetic field) and the rate of the formation and recycling of the continents and the ocean over Earth history. The results will help determine the amount of radioactive heat sources within the Earth, and the rate of recycling the water in the oceans back into the solid Earth, as well as the temporal variability of convection and plate tectonics on the Earth, and estimate how similar the present state is to previous conditions over Earth history.

The new model of boundary layer convection includes strong plates on the surface as well as viscosity layering in the mantle, which allows a much more realistic treatment of the Earth's thermal evolution than previous uniform-mantle models. The model is based on conservation of mechanical energy for the lithosphere and the upper and lower mantles, which results in an analytical formulation for heat transport, plate and convection speeds as functions of the Rayleigh number and other parameters. The dependence of the results on parameters in the model is apparent from the analytic formulation and results, unlike the case for numerical simulations. The solutions can be evaluated in seconds, compared to hours (or days) for fully numerical models. The main determinant of plate behavior is the ratio of viscous stress on the lithosphere from mantle flow to the strength of the lithosphere. Mantle stresses depend on mantle viscosity, which depends strongly on temperature and water content, and the upper and lower mantle may have different dependencies. The model allows these to be investigated efficiently, for the first time. Preliminary results already indicate that the model may resolve a longstanding discordance between geochemical estimates of mantle radioactive heating and inferences from geophysical thermal evolution models (the Urey ratio), which is a central issue related to current studies and debates about the precise composition of the Earth. The incorporation of the effects of water on rheology together with models of recycling the oceans through the mantle will contribute to investigations of variation of ocean volume over geologic time, as well as more general problems of geochemical recycling. Lastly, the general analytic formulation and realization of the model will allow its application to other planets, both within the solar system and as exoplanets around other stars.

ProgramReference.Text: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal involved studies of: (1) the structure and long term evolution of the Earth's rocky mantle; and (2) reconstructions of continental motions, tectonics and supercontinent dynamics during the Neorpoterozoic (800 million years ago).

In regard to (1), funding has been used in the past year to support the work of graduate student, Harriet Lau, who has developed an entirely new method of inferring deep mantle structure based on the analysis of the Earth's body tides (body tides are deformations akin to ocean tides, but involving the solid Earth rather than oceans). Her work has been recognized by being awarded a Graduate Student Research Award from the SEDI (Studies of hte Earth's Deep Interior) section of the American Geophysical Union. In addition she will present her work at the upcoming Fall AGU Meeting in a symposium to honor the work of Prof. Adam Dziewonski:

Harriet C.P. Lau, James Davis, Jerry Mitrovica, Jeroen Tromp, David Al-Attar, Konstantin Latychev, Hsin-Ying Yang, 2016. Tidal Tomography: New Insights into Long Wavelength Deep Mantle Buoyancy Structure. American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting.

The goal of the research is to ultimately constrain the deep mantle buoyancy (density) structure of the mantle and establish to buoyancy of the two very large structures - one below the Pacific and the other below southern Africa - that have been imaged using seismic methods. The buoyancy of these structures will govern the rate of the large scale evolution of the Earth over a period of as long a a billion years, and this understanding will, in turn, provide insight into a number of fundamental problems related to the development of the Earth's atmopshere and oceans, and the geochemical evolutionof the mantle. The research is being prepared for publication and we will acknowledge NSF support in that manuscript.

In regard to (2), the Neoproterozoic was a period in Earth history of great climatic upheaval, including global scale glaciation known as "Snowball Earth") and major luctuations in ocean geochemistry. It also involved the development of the supercontinent Rodinia and its eventual break-up, and magnetic evidence from ancient rocks preserved from this period have suggested a large scale reorientation of the rotation axis relative to the surface plates (a process formally callled true polar wander). Understanding the evolutionof the Earth system during this period is crucial to our understanding of the natural factors that combine to driven instability (and stability) of the planet and its climate. The funding from this proposal supported the work of graduate student, Athena Eyster for 16 months during the period 07/2013-09/2014. This work has led to a revised model for the drift of the continent Laurentia during the Neoproterozoic, which inturn will improve estimates of true polar wander during the period. The work related to the project was presented at three meetings:

Eyster, A. E., O’Connell, R. J., Macdonald, F. A., 2014, Testing links between mantle plumes and true polar wander. American Geophysical Union Fall meeting.

Eyster, A. E. and Macdonald, F. A., O’Connell, R. J., 2014, Large Igneous Provinces, True Polar Wander and the Explosion of Life. Northeastern Geobiology Symposium, Yale University.

Eyster, A. E., O’Connell, R. J., 2013, Conditions Necessary for a Mantle Plume to Initiate Large Rapid True Polar Wander, American Geophysical Union Fall meeting.

Moreover, there are two papers in preparation that are related to work funded by this proposal:

Eyster, A. E., Weiss, B. P., Karlstrom, K. E. Macdonald, F.A., in prep, New paleomagnetic data from the Neoproterozoic Chuar Group.

Eyster, A. E., and Macdonald, F.A., in prep,  A comprehensive 1000-720 Ma apparent polar wander path for Laurentia and implications for tectonics and supercontinent dynamics.
